title: Pendle Hill Walk From Sabden Route

images.title: Mike and Kirsty Grundy / Main Street, Sabden
images.caption: Main Street, Sabden. Village in the shadow of Pendle Hill. Famous for many things including the Pendle witches and an alleged treacle mine. The local handloom weavers of old were said to weave parkin using oatmeal as the warp and treacle as the weft.

images.title: Mike and Kirsty Grundy / Churn Clough Reservoir nr Sabden
images.caption: Churn Clough Reservoir near Sabden. Nestling under Pendle Hill.

images.title: Gerald England / CC BY-SA (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)
images.caption: The view towards Sabden from the Nick of Pendle

images.title: Jon Royle / Pendle Hill
images.caption: Taken from the Nick'o'Pendle looking NNE across Pendleton Moor onto Mearley Moor, the southwest end of Pendle Hill.

images.title: Richard Johnson / Nick of Pendle and Sabden
images.caption: Nick of Pendle and Sabden Forest of Pendle. View from Car Park at Padiham Heights

images.title: John Darch / Black Hill Trig Point on a fine day
images.caption: Black Hill Trig Point on a fine day Pendle Hill in the background.

images.title: Richard Webb / On Pendle Hill
images.caption: On Pendle Hill. Looking up the final gentle slopes to the summit.

images.title: Dr Neil Clifton / View over Barley from the summit of Pendle Hill
images.caption: View over Barley from the summit of Pendle Hill

description: This walk climbs to Pendle Hill from the village of Sabden in Lancashire. The village is located a few miles south west of the hill summit and makes for an alternative start point to the Pendle Hill walk from Barley . It's about a 3 mile walk from the village so roughly 6 miles there and back. The walk starts in the village and follows footpaths north, passing Calf Hill and Churn Clough Reservoir. You continue past Badgers Well Water and Chartist's Well where you turn north east to Badgers Well Hill. The route continues past Black Hill, Pendle Moor and Ogden Clough before coming to the hill summit which stands at a height of 557 metres (1,827 ft). From here there are wonderful views over the South Pennines to the east, the Bowland Fells to the northwest, and the West Pennine Moors to the south. This walk starts from the village but you could also start from the Nick of Pendle car park which is located just to the north west of the village.
